articles.headline: Consumer Bureau Nominee Could Face ‘Bumpy Ride’ Over Lack of Experience
articles.snippet: Kathleen Kraninger, who has little experience with the consumer finance products and businesses that the watchdog agency was created to police, will be grilled by lawmakers on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Kathleen Kraninger, who has little experience with the consumer finance products and businesses that the watchdog agency was created to police, will be grilled by lawmakers on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the White House named Kathleen Kraninger in June to be the next director of a post-crisis consumer watchdog, many of the agency’s fiercest critics and its most ardent supporters had the same response: Who?

articles.headline: Trump Nominee Is Mastermind of Anti-Union Legal Campaign
articles.snippet: A conservative lawyer chosen to head a federal agency has spent months bringing cases that could bankrupt public-employee unions in several states.
articles.abstract: A conservative lawyer chosen to head a federal agency has spent months bringing cases that could bankrupt public-employee unions in several states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the Supreme Court struck down mandatory union fees for government workers last month, the next phase of the conservative legal campaign against public-sector unions was underway.

articles.headline: From the Start, Trump Has Muddied a Clear Message: Putin Interfered
articles.snippet: Weeks before taking office, Donald J. Trump learned of highly sensitive intelligence about Russian election interference, but he has done all he can to suggest other explanations for the hacks.
articles.abstract: Weeks before taking office, Donald J. Trump learned of highly sensitive intelligence about Russian election interference, but he has done all he can to suggest other explanations for the hacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks before his inauguration, Donald J. Trump was shown highly classified intelligence indicating that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had personally ordered complex cyberattacks to sway the 2016 American election.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: The Most Important Number in Finance Is Going Away. Wall St. Isn’t Prepared.
articles.snippet: Libor, a benchmark for everything from adjustable mortgages to private student loans, is set to disappear by 2021. Regulators are worried that banks aren’t taking the change seriously enough.
articles.abstract: Libor, a benchmark for everything from adjustable mortgages to private student loans, is set to disappear by 2021. Regulators are worried that banks aren’t taking the change seriously enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of finance, there is one number that arguably matters more than any other. You can find it in the small print on adjustable-rate mortgages and private student loans, it is the basis for enormous corporate loans, and it underpins nearly $200 trillion of derivatives contracts.

articles.headline: Israeli Law Declares the Country the ‘Nation-State of the Jewish People’
articles.snippet: Critics say that by giving a special status to Jews — and downgrading the status of the Arabic language — the legislation diminishes non-Jewish citizens.
articles.abstract: Critics say that by giving a special status to Jews — and downgrading the status of the Arabic language — the legislation diminishes non-Jewish citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has long demanded that the Palestinians acknowledge his country’s existence as the “nation-state of the Jewish people.” On Thursday, his governing coalition stopped waiting around and pushed through a law that made it a fact.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: The Districts Are Mostly White. The Candidates Are Not.
articles.snippet: There are only a few Democratic candidates of color in majority-white districts. Some activists say the party isn’t trying hard enough.
articles.abstract: There are only a few Democratic candidates of color in majority-white districts. Some activists say the party isn’t trying hard enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTH AURORA, Ill. — Most of the room’s occupants looked nothing like Lauren Underwood, but no one seemed to care.

articles.headline: Tariffs Imperil a Hometown Business in South Carolina: BMW
articles.snippet: The automaker became the No. 1 exporter of American-made cars, transforming Spartanburg. Now it is weighing the impact of an escalation of the trade fight.
articles.abstract: The automaker became the No. 1 exporter of American-made cars, transforming Spartanburg. Now it is weighing the impact of an escalation of the trade fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPARTANBURG, S.C. — In the middle of David Britt’s campaign to get BMW to put a car factory in this city, a man grabbed him by the tie while he was in a restaurant.

articles.headline: Trump Tried to Protect Qualcomm. Now His Trade War May Be Hurting It.
articles.snippet: Qualcomm’s chief executive, Steve Mollenkopf, needs Beijing’s regulatory approval to buy another chip maker, NXP. But a prolonged deal review by China is widely seen as retaliation for U.S. tariffs.
articles.abstract: Qualcomm’s chief executive, Steve Mollenkopf, needs Beijing’s regulatory approval to buy another chip maker, NXP. But a prolonged deal review by China is widely seen as retaliation for U.S. tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Steve Mollenkopf, the chief executive of Qualcomm, has been waiting for a phone call with news from China. It has been a long wait.

articles.headline: How 2 Media Moguls’ Once-Warm Friendship Turned Frigid
articles.snippet: The legal wrangling between CBS, Viacom and the Redstone family provides a behind-the-scenes view into how quickly a powerful business alliance can fray.
articles.abstract: The legal wrangling between CBS, Viacom and the Redstone family provides a behind-the-scenes view into how quickly a powerful business alliance can fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: When CBS filed suit to strip Shari E. Redstone of her voting control of the company in May, no one purported to be more surprised — and hurt — than Ms. Redstone herself.
